content.body: othermaciej: i'm adding doc="" to <iframe> since abarth wants to implement it -- should this be in the version we're driving to LC at the w3c, or should I keep it out like <device>?
Hixie: I think since it is an important component of making an existing feature (sandboxed iframes) viable, I would suggest it should go in the W3C copy
k
Hixie: it does not strike me as the kind of thing likely to cause huge controversy but you could send notice and an explanation to the list if you think it would help
"the list" being public-html
sure
ICYMI: blog post re: HTML5 from web designer Andy Clarke: http://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/blog/about/keep_calm_and_carry_on_with_html5
(n.b. I left a comment with my personal opinion/experience)
hi tantek
I like that the post title starts with "Keep calm"
hi othermaciej - indeed
would love to stay and chat but gotta run to tonight's microformats dinner
later
will try to be back on in a few hours later tonight
DON'T PANIC
'hmm's at the conspicuous absence of Mozilla from the combatants list in that post
and I suppose, to a much lesser degree, maybe Google
TabAtkins: are you around?
Yo
TabAtkins: I'm thinking we should assemble some of the options from http://wiki.whatwg.org/index.php?title=Change_Proposal:_figure_and_details and submit them soon
TabAtkins: I'm gonna glue together the pieces for 3 in the w3c wiki but I would be happy if in terms of submitting on the mailing list you did 6 first
Did 6 on the list, or did 6 on the w3c wiki?
I can also do 7 if you want, or you can feel free to steal my content from 3 and submit it on yourself
TabAtkins: I am expressing myself poorly and having a hard time rephrasing
let me try again
Hehe.
- For actual submission to the mailing list, I'd prefer if you sent in 6 before I send in 3.
(I guess we should also ask Lachy if he wants to be listed as co-author)
- For assembling only the relevant pieces in the right order, I'm going to do that now, in the w3c wiki, so I can just mail a link to that when ready
assuming the status quo and <legend> are non-options, from that list 2, 3, and 3b seem the best
I am going to include the names from 3b as alternatives in my 3 write-up
Yeah, I think I like 3b the best too.
I'd be willing to drop 6, since nobody else is really cheerleading it.
I could not decide which names are better (both sets seem good to me)
TabAtkins: I think it's good to have more alternatives on the table... maybe worth submitting since you did the writing and consider dropping later if no one likes it best
Eh, kk.
othermaciej: if it would save time, if the chairs can confirm that neither <dt>/<dd> nor <legend> are considered acceptable, i'd be happy to just do 3 or 3b
or some hybrid thereof
not sure which i prefer of <dlabel> and <dsummary> or if some other word would be better
Hixie: well, if no one writes a proposal defending them by the 16th, then neither will be acceptable
Hixie: I would rather not prejudge without seeing what arguments are mustered in their favor, if any
Hixie: but if you're willing to go along with one of the options presented then I do think that would save time
So, want me to write up 6 tonight?  I can do it while I'm letting the chinchillas out.
Then I can write up 7 as a diff of 3 after you do it.
if you can do 6 that would be sweet
I am now assembling 3 at http://esw.w3.org/topic/HTML/ChangeProposals/DdDtFcaptionDlabel

othermaciej: well, i can live with figcaption given that nobody seems to agree with me that we should use <legend>, and basically nobody at all seems to want <dt>/<dd>. I'm not a huge fan of <dlabel> and <dsummary>, but failing anything better I could live with one of those too.
k, watching Chopped right now, will have by midnight my time (3 hours from now)

maybe <summary>, though that would make the <table summary=""> people upset. (It would only be a problem if we kept summary="", which I don't think we should, but tying this to the summary="" issue seems like it would make the process complicated.)
Hixie: I'll probably list additional options (fcaption/figcaption/figurecaption and dlabel/detailslabel/dsummary/detailssummary/summary)
Oh god, detailssummary is the worst possible name.  Don't even suggest it.
TabAtkins: good point
same with figurecaption :-)
and detailslabel
lslslslsl
all right
fcaption/figcaption and dlabel/dsummary/summary as the options
and I may tweak which are presented as the default choice and/or leave picking one to a straw poll or editor's discretion
I'm not sure what connection <summary> could possibly have to <table summary>, except the incidental name collision.  There's nothing joining the two concepts at all, though.
the name collision primarily
also some people want a <summary> element for <caption>
Leif has also occasionally suggested a <summary> element as an extra way to give table accessibility descriptions
though imho calling a table description a summary is misleading, but that's another story
I don't see a problem, theoretically, with <caption> picking up a <summary> as well.  It's not like it would be ambiguous.
people didn't like that argument with <dt>/<dd>
True.
Eh.
<* caption> is pretty funky
fears he set a bad precedent with <time pubdate>
Heh, that is indeed the precedent I was leaning on.
http://esw.w3.org/topic/HTML/ChangeProposals/DdDtFcaptionDlabel is done
by the way, whatever flavor of wiki that is, I like it a lot less than whatever flavor the whatwg wiki is
whatwg is mediawiki, same as wikipedia
esw is moinmoin
I like the MediaWiki syntax, styling, and set of easily accessible capabilities much better than MoinMoin
apparently
231 bugs resolved so far this month, 77 still open
the influx is kinda crazy this month
othermaciej: http://esw.w3.org/topic/HTML/ChangeProposals/DdDtCaptionAttribute
TabAtkins: neat
Doing 7 right now
TabAtkins: you probably also want to copy over the general rationale against dt/dd
The hugormous section you have in yours?
the one that I copied from Lachlan's page
(I assumed the point of his page was to share at least that part of the rationale)
TabAtkins: just updated http://esw.w3.org/topic/HTML/ChangeProposals/DdDtFcaptionDlabel to have the alternate names included (figcaption, dsummary, etc)
kk.
I'm doing 7 just as a diff on that one, so no problems here.

TabAtkins: if you wanted to copy it wholesale for 7, I believe all you need to change is the Details section (two more new elements, plus change the content models of <figure> and <details> appropriately), and reverse the argument in "Does Not Introduce Redundant Elements for the Content"
to something like "Introduces Convenient Optional Elements for the Content
Yup, pretty much exactly what I'm doing.
Hmm.  Multiple <fbody>s in a <figure> - should they all be the figure content?  Like how you can have multiple <tbody>s?
I think it should only be valid to have one - no thought on what should happen if you specify multiple
othermaciej: http://esw.w3.org/topic/HTML/ChangeProposals/DdDtFbodyDbody, and I'm off to bed.
TabAtkins: right on
othermaciej, TabAtkins, i made a wordpress plugin that uses the figure / dd / dt construct: http://blog.dieweltistgarnichtso.net/html5-cc-plugin-fur-wordpress-version-0-6
what would you suggest to use until that issue is cleared ? nested divs ?
erlehmann: if we're lucky we can have this one settled within a week or two
erlehmann: don't know what I would suggest in the meantime
wish me luck then
othermaciej, i hope that will go over the mailing list again ? i normally don't read #whatwg logs.
erlehmann: hope what will go over the mailing list?
the discussion about changing figure.
there wasn't anything in the last 2 weeks concerning that if i am right ?
there will definitely be mention on public-html
I guess it would be good to also mention it on the whatwg list
oh, i don't read public-html. whatever, ping me in chat if it changes or something. thanks for the info btw :)
othermaciej, i'm guessing you posted that to the wrong list
Hixie: oops, yeah, bad habit
can't believe I didn't even notice
Hixie: whatever is causing that bug, though, it's really annoying!
i get weird hangs in safari quite a lot of i leave html5 open for a lot
s/lot/long time/
haven't filed a bug because i can't reliably reproduce it and the profiles i got from activity monitor are months old now
and i haven't seen it for a while
but that's mostly because i've been using chrome more recently
gonna have to switch to firefox for a while in a few months, to keep all the browsers with equal time on my machine :-P
Hixie: I'm pretty sure it's not the same thing unless you started serving Flash ads on the html5 spec
indeed, different issue
I have also never seen it, though opening multiple copies of the spec can make things slow for quite some time
it might be some leopard thing (i'm still on leopard on my google laptop)
ah, my bug would be SnowLeopard-specific
mmm, Flash_EnforceLocalSecurity, my favouritest symbol
roc: I know, right?
roc: someone reminded me of the Flash bug that I'm likely experiencing but there's clearly also a bug in WebKit's out-of-process plugin support in that we let the browser get hung on a Flash hang
Oh, interesting, I frequently get hangs/crashes on that in Safari. I've never bothered to investigate.
Flash_EnforceLocalSecurity is just the only function in Flash that appears to have a symbol
so all Flash crashes or hangs appear to be in that function
Oh, I see
so it's kind of a joke among browser developers
Hehe.
they should rename it to HTML5Parser or something
lol
at least the real HTML5 parser is less crashy than Flash
(would be pretty sad if that weren't the case)
(maybe the HTML5 parser on the 1.9.2 branch should be named Flash)

"Andy, you are advocating Tag Soup. Yes, nobody will die from this. However, this practice makes it more difficult for tool vendors to process HTML which increases their costs and creates an uncompetitive environment. " - http://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/blog/about/keep_calm_and_carry_on_with_html5#r4080
confusing use of quotation marks there
seems vlad has not understood that tool vendors can use off-the-shelf html5 parsers to process html, which reduces teh cost and creates a competetive environment
that seems odd
considering that Vlad is a tool vendor
indeed
and, therefore, one could expect him to be familiar with the serializer APIs
greetings
good evening
i also don't see where andy is advocating tag soup
depends on what you mean "tag soup"
he's clearly advocating early use of not-quite-yet-standard features

unless vlad considers
to be tag soup
that's valid in HTML5
maybe even advocating not worrying much about whether you follow required content models
he doesn't seem to be calling for writing stuff like foo bar baz
or in general for writing things that only get parsed sorta by accident
my interpretation is "use cutting-edge if it works and don't worry so much about it"
"tag soup" isn't a very enlightening term
well, I learned something new by reading Lachy's comment on Vlad's blog
was unaware of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia-Asia_debate
hsivonen: comment where?
(relative to British Parliamentary Style)
thought that page would be about a debate on whether Australia is a part of Asia or not
zcorpan__: http://rebuildingtheweb.com/en/invitation-html5-team/#c20100107043000
that s strangely fascinating
the kind of debate that I believe is most common in america is "forensic debate" or something like that
I read "traditional style 3 vs. 3 approach" and thought "what? isn't *traditional* 4 vs. 4"
ooh debate software
and then checked Wikipedia to see if Australia deviates from the British tradition
never heard of that before
zcorpan__: that was interesting, too
maybe the W3C should adopt parliamentary rules of debate
(and/or procedure in general)
although I would not enjoy Prime Minister's Question Hour
i thought the kind of debate that the US usually was called "the media tries to convince the candidates that they won't be made to look foolish so that they can make money on ads"
usually has, i should say
I don't think anyone considers the type of verbal challenge events that candidates for political office engage in to be a serious form of debate
othermaciej: sometimes I wish debates at the W3C were adjudicated so that one would lose for making randomly self-contradicting statements
but otherwise, I really don't welcome BP kind of debate to the W3C
hsivonen: that would be unfair to people with poor logical reasoning skills
since one of the aspects of BP is boldly making up bullshit in the hope you don't get caught
then I think we might already be on that system :-)
hsivonen: w3c debates are supposed to be adjudicated, that's what the chairs are supposed to be doing
they rarely do, for some reason that i don't understand
in the HTML WG, the chairs try to intervene to prevent abusive behavior (granted we don't always succeed) but generally prefer to avoid ruling on validity of arguments or debating tactics
picking whatever argument is convenient for supporting some agenda, even when those arguments contradict each other, is abusive behaviour.
at least imho.
in BP, the adjudicator is not supposed to rule on the vecity of bullshit but on the internal consistency of the bullshit
hsivonen, when I posted that comment, I just assumed it was a common debating technique everywhere, since that's basically the only style I group up with
and it roughly matched the style I'd seen on American TV shows
even in the W3C WGs it would be useful if the chairs called blatant logical contradictions that are detectable without judging the veracity of the arguments
yeah i'm not suggesting that subtle argumental contradictions should be called out, they are often the result of people changing their mind over time or making honest mistakes
i just mean blatent contradictions from day to day
changing one mind is different from spinning stuff on the spot
one's
right
I think it would be ok for people to just point out each other's contradictions
I am not sure contradicting yourself is per se abusive, unless used to create drama or filibuster a topic or the like
hard to say in the hypothetical
I think ad hominem is the one fallacy that is clearly nearly always abusive regardless of context
indeed
it's certainly more psychologically harmful
but even an argument from authority is generally merely invalid as opposed to abusive, and informal debate citing an authority may not even be invalid
(if it is a piece of supporting evidence rather than your whole case, say)

there is a rhetorical device used by pundits to "challenge to a one-one debate" in political circles etc. as a method of claiming victory (by lack of answer to the challenge) - I don't remember what this specific rhetorical device is called though - I'm pretty sure it has a name
othermaciej: i was refering more to someone saying "i think we should do a, not b, because z" one day and "i think we should do c, not d, because not-z" the next

othermaciej - yes, argument from authority is perhaps a weak/indirect form of evidence ("experience" or "expertise") but is both better than nothing / novice opinion, and certainly better than ad hominem or other logically flawed attacks.
othermaciej: though "i don't have to defend my position, but i will object to the hilt your suggestion that i may be wrong, and i think your arguments are irrelevant" is equally abusive, imho
however saying something like "I don't have to answer your reasoned arguments because I am the top expert in the field" would be a bad form of argument from authority
othermaciej: since it precludes compromises from being derived
yeah
Hixie: being constantly contradictory without an supporting arguments would likely be abusive
i don't see the need for <fbody> and <dbody>
refusal to compromise - that is borderline
sometimes to compromise would be unprincipled
refusal to even hear others out - that would certainly be bad form
refusal to compromise isn't abusive, but not providing any reasons such that it is impossible to even try to find other solutions that might satisfy all requirements is, imho

that's why in the whatwg i only look at the arguments, and not the volume of opinions, and occasionally come up with completely novel solutions that nobody was looking for but which people are surprisingly happy with
and why i find the polarising argument style in the htmlwg to be unproductive
sure, disagreeing without any supporting arguments is not productive
repeating the same arguments is also often unproductive
yeah
or ignoring other people's
complaining about things that are bad without specific and practical suggestions on how to make things better, also not super productive
polarizing (artificial dichotomy) only makes sense when you're appealing to emotion rather than reason ;)
i like <fcaption> and <dlabel> without explicit bodies best
zcorpan__: me too (or one of the various similar names)
not <figcaption> because it's different from <thead>
and longer
i'm not a fan of <fcaption>, but i can't work out why.
if you abbreviated further, you could bust a <dcap>
or an <fcap>
i could live with <fcaption> and <dlabel> if there's really no chance of the imho far superior <legend> :-)
(which i presume there isn't)

when I think a thread is off the rails enough to need active moderation, the main things I ask for are that people not overly repeat arguments that are already on the record, and that people focus on concrete use cases or proposals
fcaption when you pronounce it sounds vaguely like a word that means something
Hixie, a new element is superior to legend. But reusing legend is preferable to reusing any other element.
that might be what seems weird about it
it could be the name of a perfume
Effcaption... by Calvin Klein

the main problem with not compromising is that under a "can you live with it" regime, other people who normally would compromise have to also adopt an uncompromising line, because otherwise those who don't budge get their way over and over again
hsivonen: i'm not talking about compromising really but about finding solutions that are equally good for you, but also good for others
hsivonen: I don't entirely buy into "can you live with it" as the standard for anything but truly bikeshed-type issues
hsivonen: e.g. if someone wants a rail bridge and someone else wants a car ferry, it may be that a car/rail bridge would equally please both camps -- depends on their reasons
hsivonen: or it could be that a tunnel would be a solution

the W3C process on managing disagreement stresses strength of objections, and as often I like to say, I believe "strength" refers to quality of their supporting arguments, not the vehemence with which they are expressed
hsivonen: depends if the reasons are "has to carry cars" or "has to not be ugly" or "has to support freight" or "has to support tourist passenger rail cars"
in fact the W3C process specifically says you can't halt progress just by saying you cannot live with a decision
http://rebuildingtheweb.com/en/invitation-html5-team/ - hmm, I think I made all the comments disappear :-(
All I did was post one with a U+FFFF
indeed, sometimes there are better solutions outside of the box, and they can be hard to find if people are not clear about their requirements and motivations
it would be pretty bad if someone killed himself because of a decision in w3c
Philip`: Awesome. XML FTW!
Philip`: harsh
at lease i don't see an error message
The preview page just gave a well-formedness error, I didn't realise it'd break the main page like that
zcorpan__: <dbody> seems rather useful because it seems rather common to want to e.g. give some extra left margin to the details expansion
why can't <div> do that
jgraham: you can have a negative margin on dlabel
yeah or div
Hixie: It can be Why make the pattern <details><dlabel></><div class="dbody">
s/be/but/
there are lots of useful things we could add to help styling
because the real solution is power in css
don't fix css by adding elements to html
since power in CSS generally implies slowness, I guess implementors might disagree :)
(anyway it seems somewhat reasonable to have a grouping element in a situation in which we know authors will often want to deal with just the children of that element)

Hixie: a follow-up about the cvs locking problem: I'm told a change has now been made the should prevent the problem from ever recurring. But if/when you ever notice it hanging again on commits, please let me know
k
thanks
jgraham: we have a grouping element here -- <div>
that's what it's for
grouping for CSS
and script
I think <dbody> would serve no semantic or implementation-level purpose, which would make it purely a styling hook, so overall I am not sold, but I can see how it can be convenient
i'd add <di> before <dbody>
even i would add <di> before <dbody> :-)
yeah, just use <div>
it seems like "details > div" would be a fine way to add on your styling
and if dbody is optional it will be no more effective at truly catching all your details bodies than div
I want to see how pageshow fires when an iframe is inserted to the doc by the parser
should I expect to be able to inject a listered via the prototype of HTMLIframeElement somehow?
*listener
also, are Gecko and WebKit the only engines that support pageshow/pagehide?
pageshow fires on iframes?
hsivonen: yes, afaik
still hates the way pageshow is defined
Philip`: brilliant!
it would be so much better if it fired only on returning via cache and not on initial page load
othermaciej: in the spec or in UAs?
zcorpan__: I want to test if and how it fires.
i think the spec just matches what browsers do
it does
I know the name Vlad Alexander from somewhere
I think Gecko's longstanding implementation makes it impossible to change now
Philip` - that comment trick was harsh but effective.
but it's still not so good
ah yes, he works on an XHTML editor
it sucks that it fires on initial load because:
tantek: It wasn't effective since it didn't cause error messages in browsers
I think my primary objection to <div> is that it does nothing for readability. It seems like a shame to design in a patern where a <div> will likely be used more often than not
othermaciej: it's not impossible to change if changing it doesn't break sites
only effective in making a point about the ridiculousness of draconianism
a) it makes it awkward to do reinitialization that should only be done when restoring from page cache; you have to record manually whether it fired once before
b) you can't use pageshow as your sole event even for first-time init anyway; you have to use load for browsers that don't (yet) have pageshow
jgraham: if that becomes the case we can always add a different kind of <div> later
jgraham: as we did with <Section>
tantek: I think the point is more about the problems of output validation being stricter than input validation
It's okay if they're both equally strict

and if first-time init and restore share some but not all code, it's much easier to call one function from two event handlers than to make one event handler behave differently depending on if it has been invoked before
but XML is stricter than everybody's input validation
zcorpan__: sites use it - I don't know how much they depend on the Gecko semantic
tantek: I think it demonstrates that it's silly to ban arbitrary characters
i see a .presisted attribute on pageshow and pagehide events in http://webkit.org/blog/516/webkit-page-cache-ii-the-unload-event/
it's a pet peeve, bit I am not sure it is worth fighting the battle at this point
I always figured the proper rhetorical response to draconialists was to simply stop reading their arguments at the first grammatical or spelling error that they made, especially in speech.
tantek: the Name production in XML is an even worse example of spec authors banning stuff Draconianly based on aesthetics
zcorpan__: I think I've see .persisted in Gecko, too
*seen
hsivonen: Do you think it's also silly to ban things that are not really characters at all, like U+D800 or like malformed UTF-8 sequences?
zcorpan__: I guess you can just avoid ever putting code in the !evt.persisted case
zcorpan__: so it's not too terrible, just slightly suboptimal
the event's interface is PageTransitionEvent in chrome
html5 just uses Event
Philip`: I think it's reasonable to turn lone surrogates or malformed UTF-8 into REPLACEMENT CHARACTER
firefox same as chrome
hmm. so how can I add listeners via the prototype?
hsivonen, you can't.
Ah, good, looks like he fixed my comment
event listeners can only be added to instances of elements
but you can create an element and add event listeners before you add it to the DOM
I was thinking of detecting pageshow for parser-inserted iframes
hsivonen: you could use onpageshow=""
zcorpan__: is it actually supported by all browsers that fire the event?
where are you looking for this event?
hsivonen: it's supported in firefox, not in chrome
in the document with the iframe, or the doc in the iframe?
Hixie: in the parent doc
hsivonen: but it bubbles
just set a capture listener
hsivonen: doesn't fire on iframes
but why would pageshow fire on the iframe parent doc?
Hixie: I want to capture the events for iframe navigation from the parent
zcorpan__: hmm. that complicates testing
i'm not aware of a way to do that
thought an iframe was event-wise equivalent to a XUL browser
if pages can't listen to iframe pageshow from the outside, perhaps I shouldn't care about it
since it can't be compat-sensitive for about:blank if it isn't observable
pageshow has the same weirdness as the load event in being fired on window but has target document
knows way too little about the quirks of DOM events to be properly testing this stuff
I wonder what Larry's motives are for his attempt at twisting the meaning of the charter beyond any reasonable interpretation? http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/0507.html
he probably wants namespaces in html
yeah, probably
but i think he's missing the fact that both rdfa and microdata can be used to create entire vocabularies in text/html
just like namespaces in html
so...
maybe someone should ask him what kind of vocabulary can't be expressed in rdfa
I think the problem is that the charter has not been written clearly enough.
and I hope we can get these issues fixed when this group recharters next year
that's usually intentional, since otherwise the groups get never get chartered
you have to write them in a way that everyone sees what they want to see so they vote "yes"
isn't a fan of charters for wgs
rechartering will be a world of hurt, I expect
if it's really intentional, then it sucks cause it just creates an environment for charter lawyers to waste time
othermaciej, will WG members be given the opportunity to give feedback on what the new charter should say when the time comes?
hopes not
Lachy: I'm actually not very clear on how rechartering mechanics go
since it'll cause everything to get discussed again
maybe the w3c decides to not renew the charter
also I need to get to bed
Philip`, why? Otherwise, we'll end up with a mess like we have now, which was written by people who ignored outside input, especially the input from Hixie

Lachy: i don't really see the point in charters in general. People are going to work on what they want to work on, what's the point of having them go through long complicated processes to get a mailing list to work on them?

Lachy: Because it's a mess we can generally ignore, vs weeks/months of effort wasted on discussions of what should and shouldn't be in HTML and everybody trying to get the charter to say things that will support all their future arguments about everything
does the parsing definition + deference to other applicable specs constitute "a" mechanism.

Hixie, personally, I agree, but the W3C requires charters and it seems to me the only way to avoid having crazy people try to reinterpret the charter to suit their agenda is to make sure it's written clearly
Lachy: yeah but then those crazy people would vote it down
thought chartering was so companies could decide whether they risked any ip by engaging with a wg.
that's really the main practical effect of chartering
knowing the scope of IP that could be entangled
it also seems like at least a nonbinding statement of purpose for a group is useful to decide if you want to participate, regardless of IP issues
othermaciej: Agreed.
othermaciej: oh certainly a statment of purpose is useful, yes
does the <source> error event bubble per spec yet?

othermaciej: in practice i think the patent thing is only an issue for patent-hostile companies (i.e. companies that might want to use their patents to pro-actively sue someone rather than just defensively)
seems not
othermaciej: but even if a company is partially that way, it isn't like they're going to have a problem with what's in scope and what is slightly out of scope
Hixie: I'm relooking at the script element text-content BNFs, and wanted to ask if it's intended that the following be conformant:
<script type="text/javascript" src="url">
/ foo
/ bar
</script>
oops
(with double slashes instead)
why would it not be?
oh wait that's the documentation thing
yeah
no, that wouldn't be conforming
since not everything is commented out
OK
hmm, error doesn't bubble in firefox or webkit
does it bubble in ie?

Hixie: so I regard to the note in section 4.3.1.3 (the section about the script@src case) that says, "This requirement is in addition to the earlier restrictions on the syntax of contents of script elements." -- I'm trying to think of a case of script@src text contents that would conform to the 4.3.1.3 BNF on its own, but not conform to the 4.3.1.2 BNF
*in regard to
Hixie: <script src=url>/* <-- */</script> maybe?
<script src=''>//<!--<script></script>
Hixie: there's a missing end tag...
hm?
Hixie: in the above snippet, my brain finds EOF in script data escaped
yeah, seems like
that's the idea
and textContent is "//<!--<script></script>"
er
oh i see what you're saying
yes, you couldn't do this in text/html
i was giving a DOM serialisation
OK
not sure if it's possible to do it in text/html
it certainly is in XML
or via script

the context for my question is that I'm trying to figure out if there's any checking that could be added that would need to check that a document conforms both to the script@src BNF and the the script (with not src) BNF
it seems like maybe there's not
as far as conformance checking of serialized documents goes
because seems like anything that would not be conformant is going to cause a parse error first
for that case
MikeSmith: not in xhtml5
ah
wonderful
btw if whatwg.org and co are down in the coming days it's likely because of a server move

hopefully
nice

and another for forcing it

Pausing programs on Windows is fun, because some applications send DDE messages which are broadcast synchronously to every window on the system, and so they hang if some other program's window is not responding
(or something a bit like that)
So don't use Windows? :P

Does XBL2 require the binding files to be loaded synchronously?
hsivonen, from memory, I don't believe so.
oh, wait. Maybe it does.
XBL1 seems to be implemented with a synchronous load, which seems undesirable
if it wasn't syncronous, then that would make it difficult to bind events like load and pageshow to iframes using it, since you couldn't depend on the XBL being loaded before those events fired
maybe you could have an event fired when bindings are applied
or maybe xbl should delay the load event
or both

the other problem with async techniques is that since load time is often faster in local testing environments, authors may depend on bindings being loaded before something else in the page, even though that may not turn out to be the case in real world conditions.
this issue occurred with stylesheets, where authors have scripts depending on element styles being set by stylesheets earlier in the page
althogh, syncronous processing sucks for incremental loading. Maybe the best solution would be to delay events until after bindings have been loaded
Lachy: Like how the load event gets delayed by things, so everyone uses domcontentloaded or runs directly from a <script> at the end of a document to avoid the delay?
yeah

Philip`, TabAtkins - "detractor performant" means the person is a detractor (disagrees with a technology, which in itself isn't necessarily a bad thing, if they're constructive), and is a performant (is "acting out", trying to gain attention, etc.) - both of which specific types of trolls do
hates in-browsers PDFs
I have never heard the word performant being used in that sense ever.  I gathered it's meaning from structure and context, it's just definitely, um, strange.
TabAtkins, novel rather than strange
esoteric even
yes I paired the two specifically for that blog comment - I'd never seen them used like that either
I have heard "performant" used as a noun meaning "one who performs"
othermaciej, right
though it sounds more medical / psychological than "performer"
a lot of trolling is done for what they might call an "art" of "performance"
I've only ever heard it as an adjective, describing something which has good performance, in the technology sense.
TabAtkins - that's another meaning, yes.
stupid, ambiguous, context sensitive english :P
My dictionary says "A person who performs a duty, ceremony, etc., a performer."
which is not the same as an acting kind of performer

the point is that such individuals, whether intentionally or not, are more destructive than constructive toward the development of an open community based technology, either intentionally so, or unintentionally, but likely with disregard for such, and often paired with craving more attention/recognition/ego-boosting.

if you can recognize the pattern, and recognize that it is harmful to the development of the technology (and the community), then you can take action to prevent further damange

AryehGregor - AFAICT, the whole Change Proposal thing is designed to slow down and discourage spec feedback filibustering
If we had, say, a quick vote of a small group of actual members in the event of dispute, like I guess happens in most WGs, there would be no problem.
tantek, it makes it harder to raise formal complaints, but also harder to address them.
it's a mechanism designed to cope with the aforementioned "trolling"
it prevents you from spamming the group with blockers
AryehGregor - agreed
The problem is when they're being raised by people who seem to have unlimited time to pursue their agenda, and addressed by people who have actual work to do.
to get something to be a blocker you have to do a bunch of work
then the group has to do work in response

the way it is set up has enough credibility that decisions can stand and remove blockers
But the ones doing work in response are mostly people like browser developers who could more productively be, e.g., implementing the spec and providing sound feedback.

IMHO much better to admit that negative contributors exist, and kick them out per a community guidelines policy, than introduce more bureaucracy to deal with them slowly and painful with everyone else involved.

most of the WHATWG Steering Committee is browser vendors, and Hixie is motivated to meet the needs of browser vendors to the point that disputes would stop well short of kicking him
Right, exactly.
Everyone is working with the same goals, so there's very little conflict.
The problem in the W3C is people have conflicting goals.
If actual decisions are only made by people who share the same goals, you eliminate a lot of conflict.
AryehGregor - more specifically when people in your community have goals of *disruption* and/or *being noticed / gaining notoriety*, your community is kinda screwed
If you have to accommodate widely different sets of goals, you get lengthy arguments that end in bad compromises.
so you have to make a choice

So it seems to me that it's best to pretend the steering committee doesn't exist, when considering the organisation of the WHATWG, because it has no effect and there are other forces that prevent the hypothetical situations where it could have an effect
and so "like the WHATWG and have everything decided by a small fixed group of people" seems like an inaccurate characterisation

We certainly don't *need* them, but if it's going to be common to style the contents anyway (and it will be for me, at least), having a blessed element is better than using a classed div every time.

it does seem like an artificial pseudo-element for "everything inside this element except some particular part" would be useful for a lot of things
Yeah, I'll be writing up a proposal to www-style soon, once I work out how to deal with overlap problems.
If you guys have any suggestions, by the way, they'd be appreciated.  Quick overview:

::wrap(selector1[, selector2]?) would create a wrapping pseudo with its pseudo-start-tag just before each element matched by selector1, and its pseudo-end-tag just before the next sibling of the selector1-element that matches selector2.  If there is no such sibling, or if selector2 isn't specified, the pseudo-end-tag is inserted just before the end of the selector1-element's parent.
So, problem: given the structure a b c d and the css ::wrap(b,b) {} ::wrap(i,i) {}, what is the pseudo-structure?
The ::wrap(b,b) wants to produce a structure like <::wrap>a b<::wrap>c d
But ::wrap(i,i) wants to produce a structure like a <::wrap>b c <::wrap>d
Naively applying both causes misnesting.
In context, I'd be able to style figure bodies with ::wrap(figure > :first-child, figcaption),::wrap(figcaption + *) {}, and details bodies with ::wrap(dsummary + *) {}
is it a problem if pseudo-elements overlap?
Yes.  Very much so.
Imagine you specified borders on both.
Basically you want to guarantee that the CSS box structure is a tree for many of the same reasons you want to guarantee that the DOM is a tree.
how does that work for ::first-line, and elements that span multiple lines?
::first-line is extremely limited in what properties one can apply, precisely so that it can be done halfway-sanely.  It breaks itself up to avoid misnesting.
hmm, why does border not apply to ::first-line?
oh, is that why?

Because of the conflicts.

foo foo foo bar [linebreak] bar bar

p::first-line{ border: 1px solid black; } p span { border: 1px dotted red; }
What happens there?
that's basically the same test I just wrote

The answer is that the pseudostructure is actually

<::first-line>foo foo foo <::first-line>bar bar bar
but where is it defined in CSS which properties apply to ::first-line?
yeah, I get that
In 2.1, under the defifnition of first-line.
that's where I'm looking
Very last line paragraph of that section.
Just above the ::first-letter heading.
ah, yeah. I missed that when I first looked
For some reason 2.1 suggests that UAs should break up the span to keep the ::first-line intact, but that's obviously stupid and nobody does it that way afaik.
Nice, git-svn finished in less than an hour.
TabAtkins: is ::wrap() allowed to take arbitrarily complex selectors?
Yes.
does it take only a selector or group of selectors?
only a selector, so that it can use the , to separate the start-selector and end-selector, but by using the :matches() pseudoclass you can combine multiple selectors.
:matches() doens't exist yet, but it's just a matter of time.  It'll be implemeneted long before ::wrap
So, frex, you can create section wrappers in a page that uses only implied sections with ::wrap(h1,h1), ::wrap(h2,:matches(h1,h2)), etc.
Though to be fully general you'd have to deal with <hgroup> as well, and you can't do that until the :has() pseudoclass is supported.
::wrap(:matches(h1,hgroup:has(h1)), :matches(h1,hgroup:has(h1))) {}
And :has isn't going to be implementable for a while yet, apparently.
Though, that could be re-simplified with a :heading() pseudoclass.  ::wrap(:heading(1),:heading(1)) {}, ::wrap(:heading(2),:heading(2 - n)) {}, etc.
There are a number of pseudos that I want access to yesterday, obviously.  ^_^  And they should be cheaply implementable, too.
